column4: can I get some help configuring Postfix to work for sending mail from Thunderbird?  it keeps asking for my password over and over.  there are some error messages in my /var/log/mail.info about SASL authentication failing.
you want to use sasl authentication for mail?
I just followed the wiki.  I actually don't want to use any crazy authentication or super encryption, but I have no idea how to configure it otherwise.

the default for postfix should be ordinary password authentication.  First thing I would do is check the postfix configuration and see what it is expecting as far as passwords.  I use the webmin plugin for postfix, it is quite good for a web interface to the postfix server
the funny thing is it works for IMAP but not for sending email.
I disabled SASL authentication and now it tells me "relay access denied"
you have to give it a list of either machines or networks allowed to send using that mail server
because of email relaying problems, the default configurations for all the mail servers disallow mail from any machine other than the host on which the server is running
usually you just need to tell it to allow mail sending from the same subnet as the server runs on.
well, I want it to allow mail sending from the whole internet, but authenticate with a username and password.
then you'll have to set the config to allow sending from anywhere.  doing that without using password encryption is not usually a good idea
that's fine, any password encryption method is acceptable
well, any of the standard methods are acceptable, and ssl is certainly an acceptable way to do it.
do you know how to do this, or where to find a guide for it?  the Ubuntu wiki uses only TLS and is very paranoid about using encryption
sorry, I don't know of any docs for it.  It's one of the choices you'll see in webmin.
how did you install webmin?
I think there is a package for it
no, I just fired up the postfix plug in and it was very easy
yes, isn't it?
I'm not finding those SSL and TLS options though
I know there are options for handling different connection types.  Keep looking.  There are several screens and it isn't always obvious which one you need to be using.
